headline.print_headline: National Briefing | West; California: Not-Guilty Plea to Gun Charge in Massacre
headline.main: Enrique Marquez Pleads Not Guilty in San Bernardino Massacre Case

snippet: Trial is set for Feb. 23 for Mr. Marquez, who is accused of supplying weapons to the couple, Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik, who killed 14 people in San Bernardino....
abstract: Enrique Marquez of California pleads not guilty to charges he supplied Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik with the two assault weapons they used to kill 14 people in San Bernardino, California shooting; Marquez's trial is set for late February.
lead_paragraph: Trial is set for Feb. 23 for Mr. Marquez, who is accused of supplying weapons to the couple, Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik, who killed 14 people in San Bernardino.

headline.print_headline: World Briefing | The Middle East; Lebanon: New Skirmish Between Israel and Hezbollah in Disputed Territory

snippet: The militant group said the assault in a disputed border area was a response to Israel’s killing of Samir Kuntar, a Hezbollah operative, last month....
abstract: Roadside bomb placed by Hezbollah forces as part of attack against Israeli-occupied Sheeba Farms strikes military vehicles but causes no causalities; Israel responds by firing artillery into southern Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: The militant group said the assault in a disputed border area was a response to Israel’s killing of Samir Kuntar, a Hezbollah operative, last month.

snippet: The group will retreat into the desert, just as it did in 2007. But can we stop it from re-emerging?...

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

abstract: Op-Ed article by author and Middle East expert Hassan Hassan argues retaking Mosul, Iraq, from Islamic State will merely force militant group into desert to regroup and sow chaos with terrorist attacks; notes group has publicly promoted this strategy and previously employed it to devastating effect in Iraq between 2007 and 2013.
lead_paragraph: The group will retreat into the desert, just as it did in 2007. But can we stop it from re-emerging?

headline.print_headline: Blast Spurs Familiar Look Inward for New Yorkers
headline.main: After Blast, New Yorkers Examine Themselves for Psychological Shrapnel

snippet: A walk around Manhattan in the wake of the Saturday night explosion revealed residents conducting their own interior investigations....
abstract: Bombing in Chelsea spurs many New York City residents to look inward as they face uncertainty, anxiety and fear that there could be more attacks.
lead_paragraph: A walk around Manhattan in the wake of the Saturday night explosion revealed residents conducting their own interior investigations.

byline.contributor: J. David Goodman, Lauren Hard and Emily Palmer contributed reporting.
byline.original: By MICHAEL WILSON, SAMANTHA SCHMIDT and SARAH MASLIN NIR

headline.print_headline: In a Comeback Bid, Sarkozy Trumpets France’s ‘Identity’ in the Face of Anxiety
headline.main: Nicolas Sarkozy Mounts What He Hopes Is a Comeback in France

snippet: In most other political systems he would be a has-been. Yet in a France under terrorist threat, Mr. Sarkozy may be the man of the moment in a presidential race....
abstract: Former French Pres Nicolas Sarkozy, who has suffered election defeat, judicial inquiries and low public approval, is making political comeback amid anxieties over immigration, terrorism and deterioration of national identity; intends to run in Republican party's primary.
lead_paragraph: In most other political systems he would be a has-been. Yet in a France under terrorist threat, Mr. Sarkozy may be the man of the moment in a presidential race.

headline.print_headline: U.S. Strikes Help Libyans Move on Surt Against ISIS
headline.main: U.S. Strikes Help Libyan Forces Against ISIS in Surt

snippet: The new round of airstrikes came as Libyan forces were reported to be making advances in their months-old offensive to oust the Islamic State from Surt....

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

abstract: United States intensifies bombing campaign against Islamic State in Libya, carrying out its first armed drone flights from Jordan to attack militant targets in coastal city of Surt; Pres Obama calls strikes necessary to protect American security and Libyan government.
lead_paragraph: The new round of airstrikes came as Libyan forces were reported to be making advances in their months-old offensive to oust the Islamic State from Surt.

byline.original: By HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT

headline.print_headline: Democrats Find Their Voice on Guns
headline.main: Democrats Find Their Voice on Gun Control

snippet: Hillary Clinton has used her nominating convention as other Democrats before her have not dared: to press for badly needed gun safety measures....
abstract: Editorial applauds Hillary Clinton for prominently featuring issue of gun control during her nominating convention; holds gun deaths in Ameria, which totaled 406,496 between 2001 and 2013, pose more ubiquitous threat than terrorist attacks that have been focus of Donald Trump's speeches.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has used her nominating convention as other Democrats before her have not dared: to press for badly needed gun safety measures.

headline.print_headline: Attacker in Nice Plotted for Months and Had Accomplices, Prosecutor Says
headline.main: Attacker in Nice Plotted for Months and Had Accomplices, French Prosecutor Says

snippet: There was no evidence that Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who killed 84 people on Bastille Day, had direct contact with the Islamic State....

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

abstract: Authorities say Nice, France, truck attacker Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel planned terrorist act that killed 84 people for months; no evidence has emerged linking assailant with Islamic State, contrary to militant group's claims.
lead_paragraph: There was no evidence that Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who killed 84 people on Bastille Day, had direct contact with the Islamic State.

byline.contributor: Benoît Morenne contributed reporting from Paris, and Lilia Blaise from Nice, France.

headline.main: Attacker in Nice Was Not on Terror Lists

snippet: The Paris prosecutor, François Molins, said that the attack in Nice, France, was carried out by a man, Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who was unknown to intelligence services....
lead_paragraph: The Paris prosecutor, François Molins, said that the attack in Nice, France, was carried out by a man, Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who was unknown to intelligence services.

headline.print_headline: Twice Scrutinized by F.B.I., Orlando Killer Exposes Gaps in Fighting ISIS-Inspired Acts
headline.main: Omar Mateen, Twice Scrutinized by F.B.I., Shows Threat of Lone Terrorists

snippet: Investigators now face the question of how much the killings were the act of a deeply disturbed man and how much he was driven by religious or political ideology....

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigation agents are feverishly trying to piece together clues about what might have led Omar Mateen to carry out deadly attack at Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla; early examination of Mateen’s life reveals hatred of gay people and stew of contradictions; his actions, no matter his intent, highlight difficulty for American government in trying to address new style of terrorism that includes random acts of violence inspired by Islamic State but not directed by group’s leaders.
lead_paragraph: Investigators now face the question of how much the killings were the act of a deeply disturbed man and how much he was driven by religious or political ideology.

byline.contributor: Mark Mazzetti and Eric Lichtblau reported from Washington, and Alan Blinder from Port St. Lucie, Fla. Reporting was contributed by Julie Turkewitz from Boulder, Colo.; Mujib Mashal from Fort Pierce, Fla.; Richard A. Oppel Jr. from New York; and Matt Apuzzo from Washington.
byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI, ERIC LICHTBLAU and ALAN BLINDER
